pullRequest.body:
A path in a simplicial set `X` of length `n` is a directed path comprised of `n` 1-simplices.

An `n`-simplex has a maximal path, the `spine` of the simplex, which is a path of length `n`. A simplicial set `X` satisfies the `StrictSegal` condition if for all `n`, the map `X.spine n : X _[n] → X.Path n` is a bijection.

Examples of `StrictSegal` simplicial sets are given by nerves of categories. Future work will show these are the only examples: that a `StrictSegal` simplicial set is isomorphic to the nerve of its homotopy category.

Co-Authored-By: [Mario Carneiro](https://github.com/digama0) and [Joël Riou](https://github.com/joelriou) 

---

This version contains the 2-coskeletality proof at the back of the StrictSegal file. I'm happy to move that to
(a) a separate file, called SimplicialSet/2Coskeletal.lean?
(b) a separate file in a separate PR

Just let me know.
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

@joelriou here is one of the breakout PRs you requested. I wasn't sure whether you wanted the proof of 2-coskeletality to live here or not. I'm happy to move it or cut it.

If we keep it here, then this is really the vast majority of the content of #16782, so most of the work of that PR is now here. On the other hand, this showcases which results about strict segal simplicial sets are used (relatively little).
@mo271 thanks for these suggestions. May I ask how you found the simpler proofs? As you can see, this was much more painful for me...

> @mo271 thanks for these suggestions. May I ask how you found the simpler proofs? As you can see, this was much more painful for me...

Really nothing special, I didn't use some special tool, just manual shuffling them around a bit.
One anti-pattern that was present here is the following:
```
have : long_statement := by exact short_proof_term
rw [this]
```
which can simply be replaced with 
```
rw [short proof term]
```

Another one is combining simps in one lines, so instead of 
```
simp only [foo]
simp only [bar]
simp only [baz]
```
just write
```
simp only [foo, bar, baz]
```

when it works. 

In general this pattern with lots of  `have` can often be streamlined using `convert`, `apply` or `refine`. However, I think one should keep the proof readable and don't overgolf them. 

One thing that is encouraged is to prefer simple tactics instead of more involved ones when possible, this is why I suggested to use `rfl` instead `aesop` in one place. Similarly, when `rw` works, I would prefer it over `simp only` or `simp`. But of course this presupposes knowing what tactics are more involved/expensive/powerful. 

I'm sure all these types of remarks are written down somewhere, but I looked a bit for a link and didn't find it.

Thanks @mo271. I believe I understand all of this except the `convert` tactic, which is new to me. Googling took me to some discussion of `conv => lhs/rhs` which I have seen before. Were you referring to that or something else?

I have a vague memory that `convert` might be similar to `show` or `suffices`---two other tactics I haven't yet really figured out how to use...

I meant this: 
https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Tactic/Convert.html#Mathlib.Tactic.convert

@jcommelin I thought this might interest you. Following a suggestion of @joelriou, @digama0 and I refactored our proof that nerves of categories are 2-coskeletal through the strict segal condition (that the map from the n-simplex to the path of vertices along its spine is a bijection). It occurs to me that your proof that nerves of categories are quasi-categories could be refactored similarly (and I just suggested this to someone in hopes they would adopt your wombat PR).

> @joelriou here is one of the breakout PRs you requested. I wasn't sure whether you wanted the proof of 2-coskeletality to live here or not. I'm happy to move it or cut it.
> 
> If we keep it here, then this is really the vast majority of the content of #16782, so most of the work of that PR is now here. On the other hand, this showcases which results about strict segal simplicial sets are used (relatively little).

My suggestion was to focus on the most basic properties, so that the main result in the `Coskeletal` file would come later in a separate PR.
improving the structure of some proofs slighly

```suggestion
    monotone' := fun i i' hii' => by simpa only [Fin.mk_le_mk, add_le_add_iff_right] using hii'
```

```suggestion
  rfl
```

```suggestion
    rw [f.arrow_src ⟨Fin.addNat i j, (by omega)⟩]
    congr
    refine Fin.eq_of_val_eq (Nat.mod_eq_of_lt ?_).symm
    omega
```

```suggestion
    rw [f.arrow_tgt ⟨Fin.addNat i j, (by omega)⟩]
    congr
    simp only [Fin.coe_addNat, Fin.val_succ, Nat.add_right_comm]
    refine Fin.eq_of_val_eq (Nat.mod_eq_of_lt ?_).symm
    omega
```

```suggestion
  · simp only [mkHom, Equiv.invFun_as_coe, spine_vertex, Fin.coe_addNat,
      ← FunctorToTypes.map_comp_apply, ← op_comp, const_comp, len_mk, spineToSimplex_vertex]
    congr
    exact Fin.eq_of_val_eq (Nat.mod_eq_of_lt (by omega)).symm
```

Is there a particular reason you choose for `< n + 1`? Intuitively, I would have expected `≤ n`
```suggestion
def Path.interval {n : ℕ} (f : Path X n) (j l : ℕ) (hjl : j + l ≤ n) :
```

@jcommelin I had similar instincts but I choose less than rather than less than or equal to to match the field used in `Fin n` namely `isLt : LT.lt val n`.  Here `hjl` is used to prove that `j + l : Fin (n + 1)`.

```suggestion
in `Mathlib.AlgebraicTopology.SimplicialSet.Coskeletal`.
```

```suggestion
noncomputable def spineToSimplex : Path X n → X _[n] :=
  (Equiv.ofBijective _ (segal n)).symm
```
You could even record that this is bijective in the type, by making it an equiv. That preserves a bit more structure, and when needed proofs of inj/surj/bij will be readily available.
This hints that we might want to abstract `mkOfLe ⟨j, (by omega)⟩ ⟨j + l, hn⟩ (Nat.le_add_right j l)` into a definition `edge j l hn`. What do you think?

If you think it's natural, from a readability pov, you could restructure this as
```suggestion
  suffices mkOfLe ⟨j, (by omega)⟩ ⟨j + l, hn⟩ (Nat.le_add_right j l) =
      mkOfDiag l ≫ subinterval j l hn by
    rw [this]
  ext e : 3
  unfold subinterval mkOfDiag mkOfLe
  simp only [len_mk, Nat.reduceAdd, mkHom, Hom.toOrderHom_mk, OrderHom.coe_mk,
    Fin.natCast_eq_last, comp_toOrderHom, OrderHom.mk_comp_mk, Function.comp_apply]
  match e with
  | 0 => simp
  | 1 =>
  apply Fin.eq_of_val_eq
  simp only [Fin.isValue, Fin.val_last]
  exact Nat.add_comm j l
```

I don't have experience with this concept. Do you think it will be useful to make the inverse function (ie `spineToSimplex`) part of this class? Then the inverse would be computable, so people can play with defeqs.

But it also means that this is no longer a property, but data-carrying.

I have zero opinion on this, just wanted to hear your thoughts.

The full name of this definition is `SSet.pt`. That sounds a bit too generic to me...
Should it maybe be in the `StructuredArrow` namespace instead?
What does `ran` refer to in this context? Is there some right Kan extension that isn't syntactically explicit in the type?

The use of `Fin.addNat` is problematic here because it does not do exactly what we want and there are coercions flying around. The following straightforward code still works: 
```suggestion
  vertex i := f.vertex ⟨j + i, by omega⟩
  arrow i := f.arrow ⟨j + i, by omega⟩
  arrow_src i := f.arrow_src ⟨j + i, by omega⟩
  arrow_tgt i := f.arrow_tgt ⟨j + i, by omega⟩
```
And using `j + l ≤ n` as Johan and I suggested seems better.

We may consider the `<` is a (necessary) implementation detail of `Fin`, but using `≤` is probably more convenient.
```suggestion
/-- The "inert" morphism associated to a subinterval `j ≤ i ≤ j + k` of `Fin (n + 1)`.-/
def subinterval {n} (j l : ℕ) (hjl : j + l ≤ n) :
```
The statement and proof here should be an API lemma for `subinterval` in the `SimplexCategory` file.
Similarly, you should extract a lemma `mkOfDiag_subinterval` from this.

It seems to me that this lemma could be deduced from the following lemma which holds for any simplicial set:
```lean
-- for SimplicialSet.Path.lean
lemma spine_map_subinterval {n : ℕ} (j l : ℕ) (hjl : j + l ≤ n) (x : X _[n]) :
    X.spine l (X.map (subinterval j l (by omega)).op x) =
      (X.spine n x).interval j l (by omega) := by
  sorry
```
Indeed, the proof would become:
```
... := by
  apply (segal _).injective
  rw [spine_map_subinterval X j l (by omega), spineToSimplex_spine, spineToSimplex_spine]
```

pullRequest.title: feat(AlgebraicTopology/SimplicialSet): paths and the strict segal condition
